content:
Thank you for referring this patient regarding right upper limb lymphedema which developed following treatment for grade III invasive ductal carcinoma with extensive lymphovascular invasion.

The patient underwent right mastectomy in March 2021, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy which was completed in August 2021, and radiotherapy completed in October 2021. She completed one year of adjuvant Trastuzumab therapy.

Relevant medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus requiring oral hypoglycemic agents, and migraine which is well controlled with prophylactic therapy. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease managed with regular proton pump inhibitor.

[redacted name] reports allergies to penicillin (causing angioedema) and ibuprofen (gastric irritation).

Current medications include metformin 1g twice daily, propranolol 80mg daily, omeprazole 20mg daily, and amitriptyline 10mg at night for migraine prophylaxis.

	Assessment findings
	Examination of the right upper limb demonstrated intact skin with moderate non-pitting edema extending from the dorsum of the hand to the upper arm. Tissue fibrosis was noted particularly in the lateral upper arm region.

Skin temperature was symmetrical with no evidence of infection. Stemmer sign was positive in all digits.

The mastectomy site showed well-healed surgical scarring with moderate tissue induration in the lateral chest wall.

Range of movement assessment: Right shoulder flexion limited to 110 degrees, abduction to 95 degrees. Left shoulder movement within normal limits. Elbow and wrist movements full range bilaterally.

Patient reported constant heaviness and occasional sharp discomfort, VAS score 5-6/10, particularly noticeable during overhead activities.

Bioimpedance analysis showed 18% volume difference compared to the contralateral limb.

	Diagnosis based on clinical presentation
	Severe stage II lymphedema affecting the right upper limb, with established fibrotic changes. Associated moderate lymphedema changes noted in the lateral chest wall region.

	Treatment aim and management plan
	Commence intensive decongestive lymphedema therapy incorporating manual lymphatic drainage and reduced-tension bandaging. Patient to be instructed in modified self-lymphatic drainage techniques.

Prescription of Class III flat-knit compression sleeve with separate gauntlet. Nocturnal compression recommended given severity of symptoms.

	Summary of programme of care
	Patient has attended comprehensive lymphedema education workshop. Detailed guidance provided regarding skincare, exercise modification, and compression garment maintenance.

Compression therapy protocol established: Class III (34-46mmHg) flat-knit sleeve with separate gauntlet to be worn continuously during day. Additional night-time compression garment prescribed. Three sets of garments arranged to ensure consistent compression.

Detailed instruction provided in modified self-lymphatic drainage protocol for twice-daily implementation.

	Signs and symptoms indicative of cellulitis requiring urgent GP assessment
	1. Sudden onset of increased swelling with tenderness
1. Skin redness or discoloration
1. Increased local temperature
1. Systemic symptoms including fever
1. General malaise
1. Increased tissue tension with pain

Cellulitis risk factors include skin breaks, insect bites, or underlying infection. Prompt recognition and intervention is crucial.

Please refer to updated LSN guidelines for management of lymphedema-associated cellulitis.

	Support needed with ongoing management in the community
	Current treatment plan is adequate with planned monitoring. No additional community support indicated at present.

	Alert Symptoms requiring oncology team contact:
	1. New lumps or nodules
1. Uncontrolled progressive pain
1. Unexpected rapid volume increase
1. New neurological symptoms

	Alert Symptoms requiring lymphedema team contact:
	1. Compression garment problems
1. Poor volume control despite adherence
1. Recurrent infections
1. Difficulty maintaining self-management

Follow-up arranged in six weeks for treatment response assessment. Patient informed to contact the clinic earlier if complications develop.
